content: The "Civil Rights History Project Act of 2009" recognizes the importance of individuals standing up for their rights and beliefs, as demonstrated by the Civil Rights movement. The Act aims to preserve the first-hand memories and stories of those who participated in the movement, including lesser-known individuals who made significant contributions. The "Civil Rights History Project Act of 2009" emphasizes the significance of collecting oral histories from individuals involved in the Civil Rights movement. The project aims to preserve their firsthand accounts for future generations and serve as a model for similar initiatives in museums, libraries, and universities. The Library of Congress and the Smithsonian Institution are proposed as suitable repositories for these oral histories. The Civil Rights History Project Act of 2009 aims to collect video and audio recordings of personal histories from individuals involved in the American Civil Rights movement. The project will be federally sponsored and coordinated at a national level, with the Library of Congress and the National Museum of African American History and Culture designated as repositories for these oral histories. The Civil Rights History Project Act of 2009 establishes an oral history project to collect audio and video recordings of personal histories from participants in the Civil Rights movement. The project aims to survey existing collections, solicit new recordings, and gather relevant visual and written materials. The Act establishes an oral history project to collect personal histories through audio and video recordings, visual and written materials, and create a collection available for public use through the Library of Congress and the National Museum of African American History and Culture. The Secretary will carry out duties through the Director of the National Museum of African American History and Culture, and may collaborate with other entities for consultation and partnerships. The Act allows for the collection of recordings and materials through agreements with government and private entities, as well as consultation with interested parties. The Librarian and the Secretary can procure services, accept volunteer help, and make advance payments for the project. They are required to start collecting recordings and materials promptly after the Act's enactment. The Act authorizes the collection of recordings and materials related to the Civil Rights movement, focusing on racial equality for African Americans from 1954 to 1968. The Librarian of Congress and the Secretary are encouraged to seek donations to support these activities, with funds dedicated solely to the project. Funds donated for this purpose will be deposited into a dedicated account and used solely to support these activities. The Librarian of Congress is prohibited from depositing any other funds into this account.
